description: The magnificent royal palace of the Ryugu Kingdom, home to King Neptune and his family. Located on Fish-Man Island, it is a grand underwater structure featuring ornate architecture and beautiful coral decorations. The palace serves as the seat of government for Fish-Man Island.

keyEvents.title: Journey to Ryugu Palace Begins
keyEvents.description: King Neptune escorts Luffy, Nami, Usopp, Brook, Camie, and Pappag to Ryugu Palace, beginning their formal visit to the royal residence.
keyEvents.significance: First appearance of the palace, establishing it as a major location for the arc.

keyEvents.title: Arrival at Ryugu Palace
keyEvents.description: The Straw Hats arrive at the magnificent palace, witnessing its grandeur and beauty firsthand.
keyEvents.significance: The palace becomes the central setting for important events in the Fish-Man Island arc.

culturalSignificance: Named after Ryūgū-jō from the Japanese folktale of Urashima Tarō, where a fisherman visits an underwater dragon palace. This cultural reference is deeply embedded in the location's design and purpose.
trivia: Ryugu Palace is one of the most beautiful locations shown in One Piece, with its underwater setting and elaborate coral architecture.
The palace's design draws heavily from Japanese mythology and underwater palace imagery.

description: A heavily fortified tower within Ryugu Palace where Princess Shirahoshi has been confined for her protection. The tower is designed to keep her safe from assassins and features a large door where food is delivered. Despite its protective purpose, it also serves as Shirahoshi's prison.

keyEvents.title: Luffy Meets Princess Shirahoshi
keyEvents.description: Luffy accidentally enters the Hard-Shell Tower while searching for food and encounters Shirahoshi for the first time.
keyEvents.significance: The Hard-Shell Tower is revealed as Shirahoshi's residence and the location of her first meeting with Luffy, a pivotal moment in the arc.

culturalSignificance: Represents both protection and imprisonment, symbolizing Shirahoshi's isolation from the world despite her royal status.
trivia: Shirahoshi has been confined to this tower for years due to constant assassination attempts.
The tower's name reflects its hard, protective shell-like design meant to keep danger out.
